projects.name: Gelenkmodule (Joint Modules)

steps.instruction: Fold the A5 paper in half, leaving a 2mm gap from the top edge. This creates two creases in the middle that form the joint between modules.
steps.visual_description: A green paper rectangle is shown. A matchstick is placed near the top edge, indicating a 2mm gap. The paper is folded in half.

steps.instruction: The diagonal fold from the center of the narrow side to the center of the wide side, i.e., to the end of the upper fold, marks the center line between the two equally sized triangles of the module.
steps.visual_description: A green paper rectangle is shown folded in half. A diagonal fold is made from the center of one side to the center of the opposite side, creating a crease that marks a center line.

steps.instruction: The bottom edge of the large isosceles right-angled triangle runs along the upper center crease, while the tip of the small triangle points to the diagonal fold.
steps.visual_description: A green paper shape is shown. The bottom edge of a large triangle aligns with a horizontal crease. The tip of a smaller triangle points towards a diagonal crease.

steps.instruction: The finished joints are shown below in front and back views. 3 outer and 6 middle joint modules are needed.
steps.visual_description: Three finished green origami modules are shown in a row. They are folded into a diamond-like shape with internal folds.

tips: For the connectors (joint modules), 12 sheets of A7 paper (4 from one A5 sheet) can be used. Copy paper (80 g/m짼) can also be used. If the middle double fold is moved back and forth sufficiently often, even thicker paper will be sufficiently flexible.
The finished model, when assembled as a cube, has an edge length of approx. 8 cm.
projects.finished_product_description: Flexible joint modules for a modular origami model, possibly a cube.

diagram_descriptions: A series of four images showing the process of folding a green paper module. The first image shows a rectangular sheet of green paper with a matchstick indicating a 2mm gap from the top edge. The second image shows the paper folded in half. The third image shows a diagonal fold being made. The fourth image shows the resulting folded shape with a prominent diagonal crease.
Three images showing the completed joint modules, viewed from different angles, demonstrating their flexibility and how they connect.

projects.name: Tetrahedron Module

steps.instruction: To avoid unsightly creases across the large triangles of the tetrahedron module, mark only the centers of the top and bottom edges as mountain folds. Fold the sides to the markings and then fold in half in the middle. In one rectangle, fold the diagonals, and in the other, fold at a 45째 angle.
steps.visual_description: A sequence of images showing a blue sheet of paper being folded. The first image shows a paper folded into three vertical sections. The second shows it folded in half horizontally. The third shows creases forming a grid. The fourth and fifth show diagonal folds being made. The sixth shows a corner being folded at a 45-degree angle.

steps.instruction: Extend the top marking to the intersection point of the diagonals. Then, press the two triangular surfaces together along the marking line, fold to the right, and fix by turning the right-hand protruding triangle inwards. Finally, turn the left-hand protruding triangle into the resulting pocket.
steps.visual_description: A sequence of images showing the paper being further folded. The first image shows the paper with the previous folds. The second shows two triangular flaps being pressed together. The third shows a flap being folded to the right. The fourth shows a triangle being tucked inside. The fifth shows the other triangle being tucked inside.

steps.instruction: Insert a symmetrical joint module with the matching side over a corner of a tetrahedron module and refold the 'diagonal' fold, thereby transferring it to the tetrahedron; repeat the process accordingly on the other corner.
steps.visual_description: A sequence of images showing two modules being joined. The first image shows two completed modules, one blue and one green. The second shows the blue module being attached to the green module. The third shows a fold being made to secure the connection. The fourth shows the completed tetrahedron module.

projects.finished_product_description: A tetrahedron module made of folded paper.

diagram_descriptions: A title 'Tetraedermodule' is displayed above a series of images illustrating the folding process of a paper tetrahedron module.
A series of images showing the step-by-step folding of a blue paper to create a tetrahedron module.
A series of images showing the joining of two paper modules (one blue, one green) to form a larger structure, likely a tetrahedron.
A final image showing a completed tetrahedron module, partially assembled with another module.

projects.name: 12 Months Ring (Modular Tetrahedron Ring)

steps.instruction: Fold the left side up over the top part. Using a bone folder on the right side, refold the protruding strip along the tetrahedron edge and along the "diagonal" fold, so that the surface lies flat when folded up.
steps.visual_description: A partially folded origami module, green on the outside and light blue on the inside, showing an open, box-like structure with triangular flaps. A hand is shown holding the module, demonstrating a fold, and another image shows a hand using a bone folder to flatten a crease on the blue inner section.

steps.instruction: To complete the tetrahedron, attach a suitable outer and a middle joint module to the surfaces; slide the left surface with the joint into the cavity and the right surface with the joint together under the movable triangle in the cavity until it stops, until all surfaces lie flat.
steps.visual_description: A completed single tetrahedron module, green and light blue, showing its three-dimensional form. Subsequent images show multiple colorful tetrahedron modules being connected in a zigzag chain.

steps.instruction: Now, one after another, another tetrahedron module and another suitable joint module are attached to one of the joint modules in the same manner, until a zigzag-shaped chain  as seen in the picture  is formed.
steps.visual_description: A long zigzag chain of colorful tetrahedron modules. The modules are in various colors including yellow, brown, orange, red, dark green, and light blue, demonstrating the sequential connection.

steps.instruction: With the tips of the tetrahedrons pointing outwards, a ring is now formed, and the last joint module is slipped over and inserted into the last free corner of the tetrahedron module at the other end of the chain. This closes the "12 Months" ring, and it is ready to play. Have fun!
steps.visual_description: Images show the zigzag chain being closed into a ring. A hand is visible inserting the final module to complete the circular structure. The finished ring is shown in a hexagonal configuration, and also transformed into a star-like shape and a cube-like shape, displaying its modular and transformable nature.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The project involves creating individual tetrahedron modules and then interlocking them sequentially to form a flexible chain, which is then closed into a ring. The ring can be manipulated into various shapes.

projects.finished_product_description: A modular origami ring, referred to as the '12 Months Ring', made from interconnected tetrahedron modules. It is transformable and can be arranged into different shapes such as a star, a cube-like form, or a hexagonal ring.

diagram_descriptions: A series of images illustrating the folding and assembly process of a modular origami project. The first row shows the initial steps of folding a single tetrahedron module, including a close-up of a hand using a bone folder to crease a fold. The second row displays a completed single module and then the sequential connection of multiple colorful modules to form a zigzag chain. The third row demonstrates the process of closing the chain into a ring, with a hand guiding the final connection, and shows the completed hexagonal ring. The fourth row showcases the finished modular ring transformed into different configurations: a star shape, a compact cube-like shape, and the hexagonal ring again from a different angle.

projects.name: Two Swans

steps.instruction: Begin with the Bird Base. Pull apart the top flaps until the central triangles open.
steps.visual_description: A diamond-shaped Bird Base is shown. The top two flaps, labeled 'a' and 'b', are indicated with curved arrows showing them being pulled outwards and downwards to open the central triangles.

steps.instruction: This is a 3D view. Do a rabbit ear. The flap behind should go to the opposite side. This will flatten the model.
steps.visual_description: A 3D perspective view of the model, which is an elongated, flattened shape. A rabbit ear fold is being performed on the bottom central part, with a curved arrow indicating the flap being moved to the opposite side to flatten the structure.

steps.instruction: Fold the model.
steps.visual_description: A flattened, elongated hexagonal shape is shown. A curved arrow indicates a rotation or turning of the model.

steps.instruction: Perform multiple folds as indicated.
steps.visual_description: A flattened, elongated hexagonal shape with numerous dashed lines indicating valley folds. Two curved arrows show folds being made towards the center from the top and bottom edges.

steps.instruction: Continue folding as indicated.
steps.visual_description: A more elongated, flattened shape. A curved arrow indicates a fold being made on the right side of the model, possibly a squash fold or similar, with dashed lines showing existing creases.

steps.instruction: Perform an inside reverse fold.
steps.visual_description: A very elongated, flattened shape. A large white arrow points downwards to indicate a fold. A curved arrow shows an inside reverse fold being performed on the right tip of the model.

details.description: A complex crease pattern for the Two Swans model, showing a square with numerous fold lines, including diagonal and grid lines, and intricate internal folds forming a central square and radiating lines, indicating the structure for the two swans.

projects.finished_product_description: A double swan origami model, designed from a single square. The diagrams present two folding paths: one simple, resulting in two swans of the same color without color change; the other more difficult, involving color change and interrupted folds. The finished model has a ratio of 0.24 x 0.39.

Step 3: Diagram of a flattened, elongated hexagonal shape with a curved arrow indicating rotation or turning.
Step 4: Diagram of a flattened, elongated hexagonal shape with multiple dashed lines indicating valley folds and curved arrows showing folds being made towards the center.
Step 5: Diagram of a more elongated, flattened shape with a curved arrow indicating a fold on the right side.
Step 6: Diagram of a very elongated, flattened shape with a large white arrow pointing downwards and a curved arrow showing an inside reverse fold being performed on the right tip.

projects.name: Origami Swan

steps.instruction: Pull down and rotate the triangular flap counter-clockwise, releasing the trapped layers of paper.
steps.visual_description: A partially folded origami base. A triangular flap on the left is shown being rotated counter-clockwise with a large curved arrow. A white arrow points to a layer being pulled out from under the flap. A dashed line indicates a previous fold line.

steps.instruction: The piece now has a vertical section on the left and a horizontal section extending to the right. The height of the vertical section is indicated.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 7, now with a vertical section on the left and a horizontal section extending to the right. A double-headed arrow with the label '6-7' indicates the height of the vertical section.

steps.instruction: The origami piece is now symmetrical, standing upright. The two side flaps are folded upwards, meeting at the top.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 8, now folded into a symmetrical, upright shape resembling a boat or stylized bird body. The two side flaps are folded upwards, meeting at the top.

steps.instruction: Open the wing flap and pull down, releasing trapped layers of paper. Repeat this process on the back side.
steps.technique: opening flap, pulling down, releasing layers
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 9. The right wing flap is shown being opened and pulled downwards. Curved arrows illustrate the motion of opening and pulling down. A dotted line indicates the new fold line. An 'X' marks a point on the flap.

steps.instruction: This is the result of the previous step.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece is now a long, narrow, symmetrical shape with pointed ends. The previously opened wing flap is now integrated, making the bottom part wider.

steps.instruction: Unwrap only the shaded layer behind to perform a color-change.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 11, with the right side shaded darker to indicate a different color or layer. A curved arrow shows a layer being unwrapped from the right side, revealing the lighter color underneath.

steps.instruction: The right side is now lighter (unwrapped). A new valley fold is indicated on the right side, folding a small triangular section inwards.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 12, with the right side now appearing lighter due to unwrapping. A new valley fold is indicated on the right side, folding a small triangular section inwards. A dashed line shows the fold line.

steps.instruction: Color-change the rest of the wing by wrapping the right side of it with paper from behind.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 13. The top right section of the wing is being 'color-changed' by wrapping a layer from behind. A curved arrow illustrates the wrapping motion. A dotted line indicates the fold.

steps.instruction: This is the result of the previous step.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 14, with the top right section of the wing now appearing as a different color or layer due to the wrapping. The overall shape remains elongated and pointed.

steps.instruction: Perform a rabbit ear fold to redo the wing.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 15. A curved arrow indicates a 'rabbit ear' fold being performed on the top section of the wing. Dashed lines show the new fold lines for the rabbit ear.

steps.instruction: Valley fold the wing to the right. Then, turn the piece over.
steps.visual_description: The origami piece from step 16. The wing on the right side is being valley folded to the right. A curved arrow shows the folding motion. A small curly arrow indicates the instruction to 'turn over'.

tips: If you want both swans to have the same color, skip to step 21.

projects.name: Swan

steps.instruction: Rabbit ear.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing a folded paper shape with an arrow indicating a fold to create a 'rabbit ear'.

steps.instruction: Color-change the front layer of the right flap.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the previous shape with a flap being folded and an arrow indicating a turning motion.
A diagram showing the previous shape with an arrow indicating a fold to the right.

steps.instruction: Double rabbit ear.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the previous shape with an arrow indicating a fold and a dashed line suggesting an internal fold. An arrow points to the right, and a hand symbol indicates pressing down.

steps.instruction: Crimp three times (or more if you have enough paper).
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the previous shape with three small arrows pointing down onto a section of the paper, indicating crimping. An arrow curves upwards.

steps.instruction: Open the head by folding up the layer behind.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the previous shape with a section being lifted and folded upwards. An oval highlights a part of the fold.

steps.instruction: Sink an small amount of the point and pleat to form the beak.
steps.visual_description: A diagram within an oval showing a pointed section with dashed lines indicating folds. An arrow points downwards onto the point, and smaller arrows indicate pleating.

steps.instruction: Close the head again by mountain folding.
steps.visual_description: A diagram within an oval showing the previously formed beak section being folded closed with a curved arrow indicating the direction of the fold.

steps.instruction: Repeat steps 21 to 25 on the other flap (swan).
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the partially formed swan with an arrow pointing to the other side, indicating repetition of steps 21-25. The label '21-25' is shown.

steps.instruction: Lift up a layer from the wing. While doing this, move the entire structure to the left using an squash fold and a pleat on the front layer of the wing. If you hold the circled area the process may get easier.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the swan's wing being lifted and manipulated. Arrows indicate movement to the left and a squash fold. A circled area is highlighted.

steps.instruction: Squash fold a lower section of the wing.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the swan's wing with a lower section being squash folded. Arrows indicate the folding action.

steps.instruction: Repeat steps 27 and 28 on the other wing.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the swan with arrows indicating repetition of steps 27 and 28 on the opposite wing. The label '27-28' is shown.

steps.instruction: Shape the model by doing some pleats on the wings. Round the neck of the swans and to a little twist so they will face each other. Do some other shapings as you like.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the completed origami swan, with emphasis on the shaping of the wings and the necks of two swans facing each other. The overall shape is that of two swans intertwined.

projects.finished_product_description: A pair of origami swans facing each other, with detailed wings and necks.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram for step 18: A vertical paper shape with a dashed line in the center, and an arrow indicating a fold to create a 'rabbit ear'.
Diagram for step 19: The shape from step 18, with a flap being folded and an arrow showing a turning motion.
Diagram for step 20: The shape from step 19, with an arrow indicating a fold to the right.
Diagram for step 21: The shape from step 20, with an arrow indicating a fold and a dashed line for an internal fold. A hand symbol indicates pressing down.
Diagram for step 22: The shape from step 21, with small arrows indicating crimping folds on a section of the paper.
Diagram for step 23: The shape from step 22, with a section being lifted and folded upwards, highlighting a fold.
Diagram for step 24: An oval containing a pointed section with dashed fold lines. An arrow points down, and smaller arrows indicate pleating to form a beak.
Diagram for step 25: An oval containing the beak section being folded closed with a curved arrow.
Diagram for step 26: The partially formed swan with an arrow pointing to the other side, indicating repetition of steps 21-25.
Diagram for step 27: The swan's wing being lifted and manipulated with arrows showing movement and a squash fold.
Diagram for step 28: The swan's wing with a lower section being squash folded.
Diagram for step 29: The swan with arrows indicating repetition of steps 27 and 28 on the opposite wing.
Diagram for step 30: The completed origami model showing two swans intertwined, with detailed wings and necks.

projects.name: Penguin

steps.instruction: Start with a kite base. Fold the top point downwards.
steps.visual_description: A kite-shaped paper base is shown with a vertical center crease and horizontal dashed lines. An arrow indicates folding the top point down.

steps.instruction: Fold the top layer down along the horizontal crease line.
steps.visual_description: The model now forms a trapezoid with a triangular flap at the top. A horizontal dashed line and a downward arrow show the top edge being folded down.

steps.instruction: Fold the side flaps inwards towards the vertical center line.
steps.visual_description: The model has a central triangular peak and two side flaps. A horizontal arrow indicates folding the right side flap inwards.

steps.instruction: Fold the entire model in half vertically. Then, fold the top-right corner downwards to begin forming the head.
steps.visual_description: The model is folded in half, creating a vertical profile. An arrow shows the top-right corner being folded down, and another arrow indicates a fold on the right side.

steps.instruction: Perform an inside reverse fold on the tip of the head to create the beak. Also, fold the top point of the head down.
steps.visual_description: The model shows the head and body. An arrow indicates folding the top point of the head down. Another arrow points to an internal fold on the tip of the head, suggesting a reverse fold for the beak.

steps.instruction: Shape the feet by making small folds at the bottom of the model.
steps.visual_description: The finished penguin shape is shown. Double arrows indicate shaping the bottom part (feet) with small folds.

projects.finished_product_description: An origami penguin.

diagram_descriptions: Origami step 1: Shows a kite base with the top point being folded down.
Origami step 2: Shows the result of the first fold, with the top layer being folded down along a horizontal crease.
Origami step 3: Shows the side flaps being folded inwards towards the center.
Origami step 4: Shows the model folded in half vertically, with the top-right corner being folded down to form the head.
Origami step 5: Shows the head being shaped with an inside reverse fold for the beak and the top point folded down.
Origami step 6: Shows the finished origami penguin with the feet being shaped by small folds.
